repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3716
Hopefully fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3741 (but I can't produce a working test for it; @KmolYuan could you look at my C++ testcase and tell me what I've missed!)
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3734

comment_data.body:
In this case the reason that the two bits of utilitycode don't match (and so it's generated "twice") is that the arguments have different names. One generates:

```
def wrap(object x, object r)
```

and the other

```
def wrap(object x1, object r)
```

There's a few options here:
1. Don't include the argument names in the wrapping: they're pure C functions and so the arguments should be viewed as positional only. The utility code will be detected as identical and eliminated. This is my view, but it may break existing code.
2. Include the argument names in the generated c name (since it's part of the "signature" kind of) thus creating two different conversion functions but making them unique.
3. Add a number to the end of the function if needed (what this PR is currently doing).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@
+# mode: run
+
+# There were a few cases where duplicate utility code definitions (i.e. with the same name)
+# could be generated, causing C compile errors. This file tests them.
+
+from __future__ import print_function
+
+cdef f1(x, r):
+    return "f1"
+
+cdef f2(x1, r):

@@ -3219,8 +3219,19 @@ def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
         if not self.can_coerce_to_pyobject(env):
             return False
         from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+
+        # include argument names into the c function name to ensure cname is unique
+        # between functions with identical types but different argument names
+        from .Symtab import punycodify_name
+        def arg_name_part(arg):
+            if arg.name:
+                return "%s%s" % (len(arg.name), punycodify_name(arg.name))
+            else:
+                return "0"

comment_data.body: Maybe it's just an "extern" missing as visibility somewhere? Because that's what parsing a `.pxd` file should give us, declarations external to the current module.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -288,8 +288,9 @@ def create_pyx_as_pxd_pipeline(context, result):
     for stage in pyx_pipeline:
         pipeline.append(stage)
         if isinstance(stage, AnalyseDeclarationsTransform):
-            # This is the last stage we need.
-            break
+            # crude hack to not generate pickle code for classes cimported
+            stage._inject_pickle_methods = lambda node: None

@@ -3219,8 +3219,19 @@ def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
         if not self.can_coerce_to_pyobject(env):
             return False
         from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+
+        # include argument names into the c function name to ensure cname is unique
+        # between functions with identical types but different argument names

comment_data.body: Yes - that's probably right. I'll have a look...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -288,8 +288,9 @@ def create_pyx_as_pxd_pipeline(context, result):
     for stage in pyx_pipeline:
         pipeline.append(stage)
         if isinstance(stage, AnalyseDeclarationsTransform):
-            # This is the last stage we need.
-            break
+            # crude hack to not generate pickle code for classes cimported
+            stage._inject_pickle_methods = lambda node: None

comment_data.body:
It looks like what actually controls pickle function generation is `scope.implemented`. This is set in `CClassDefNode.analyse_declarations` according to whether `in_pxd` is set. I've therefore made a change to set `in_pxd` just prior to the `analyse_declarations` stage.

With that says, it feels like quite a drastic change with the potential to break stuff, so I'm not really convinced its the right thing to do either.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -288,8 +288,9 @@ def create_pyx_as_pxd_pipeline(context, result):
     for stage in pyx_pipeline:
         pipeline.append(stage)
         if isinstance(stage, AnalyseDeclarationsTransform):
-            # This is the last stage we need.
-            break
+            # crude hack to not generate pickle code for classes cimported
+            stage._inject_pickle_methods = lambda node: None

comment_data.body:
I'd rather say this should have been done right from the start, and is the right thing to change in 3.0.

Your change is obviously a quick shot to try it out. In the end, this should be done right after parsing. Ideally, we'd follow the `.pxd` transformations from that point on (such as `PxdPostParse`), but some of it might fail in a `.pyx` parsed tree (which would contain a lot of stuff that is illegal in `.pxd` files). Maybe we could get there by cleaning the tree somehow. Probably not something to do right now.

I think the `in_pxd` attributes only occur on `StatNode`s, not arbitrary `Node`s. Intercepting on those should be enough.

I'm not sure how `inline` functions should behave. The author of a `.pyx` file would probably consider them local, but cimporting from it would allow them to "leak" into other modules. That could lead to problems when the function depends on other globals defined in the `.pyx` module. I'd rather disallow `inline` functions to be cimported from `.pyx` files.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -288,8 +288,9 @@ def create_pyx_as_pxd_pipeline(context, result):
     for stage in pyx_pipeline:
         pipeline.append(stage)
         if isinstance(stage, AnalyseDeclarationsTransform):
-            # This is the last stage we need.
-            break
+            # crude hack to not generate pickle code for classes cimported
+            stage._inject_pickle_methods = lambda node: None

comment_data.body:
Right. For the moment I've just changed `Node` -> `StatNode` and not changed anything else.

As you say, it'd be better to put cimported `.pyx`s through as much of the same pipeline as `.pxd` files as possible. But that probably should be done separately. It possibly might be best to just cimported pyx part of this PR rather than changing this bit twice? I'm not really sure.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -288,8 +288,9 @@ def create_pyx_as_pxd_pipeline(context, result):
     for stage in pyx_pipeline:
         pipeline.append(stage)
         if isinstance(stage, AnalyseDeclarationsTransform):
-            # This is the last stage we need.
-            break
+            # crude hack to not generate pickle code for classes cimported
+            stage._inject_pickle_methods = lambda node: None

comment_data.body:
This is a bit quicker:
```suggestion
        visit_Node = VisitorTransform.recurse_to_children
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -285,11 +285,26 @@ def create_pyx_as_pxd_pipeline(context, result):
                                            FlattenInListTransform,
                                            WithTransform
                                            ])
+    from .Visitor import VisitorTransform
+    class SetInPxdTransform(VisitorTransform):
+        # a number of nodes have an in_pxd attribute which affects AnalyseDeclarationsTransform
+        # (for example controlling pickling generation)
+        # set this
+        def visit_StatNode(self, node):
+            if hasattr(node, "in_pxd"):
+                node.in_pxd = True
+            self.visitchildren(node)
+            return node
+
+        def visit_Node(self, node):
+            self.visitchildren(node)
+            return node

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        # A number of nodes have an "in_pxd" attribute which affects AnalyseDeclarationsTransform
        # (for example controlling pickling generation). Set it, to make sure we don't mix them up with
        # the importing main module.
        # FIXME: This should be done closer to the parsing step.
```

commit.message: Hopefully fixed some issues with duplicated utilitycode

Fix issue with going out to builtin scope

Added (failing) test for #3734
Unique cfunc names, kill pxd pickle code, revert other changes
